Is the board home made or?  For a start, go here: https://stm32world.com/wiki/DIY_STM32_Programmer_(ST-Link/V2-1) and compare your schematics with the one there.  Which STM32F103? (CB with 128 kB flash is needed for all features).  Do you have the DP line pull up?  The pull-up is NOT build in on the STM32F103.  Can you run any other firmware enabling the USB?  Notice the rather strange pull-up circuitry ST themselves use.  That is necessary in order to get smooth updates.

messages.content:
Developing a dc dc 6kW converter on stm32g474.
For now I'm using internal adc but have to shift to external adc considering my sense range.
Anyone can suggest a good adc with sync analogue sampling.
I think you need to provide at least samples/sec and accuracy
Converter will run on a super loop of 20us.
I want 16 bit resolution.
I've worked with ads8688 but it doesn't provide sync sampling.
How about https://www.analog.com/media/en/technical-documentation/data-sheets/ad7389-4.pdf
Not sure it provides sync'd sample either.
AD7389-4 says "Simultaneous sampling"
However; very pricey
0 to Vref says its datasheet
Vref is 2.5V
so?

How is that beneficial from stm32
0 to 3.3V
It is talking about input levels on the analog side, right?
Yes.

Ads8688 has programmable internal reference.
It provides a bipolar range of 10V

Solve externally? I saw the AD7389-4 has differential inputs, but haven't checked if it handles +/-, but I would assume it does. Then it is just a 4:1 voltage divider... Without knowing your exact application it is difficult to give great advice.

Let's I'm measuring a current range upto 140A.
Now for it to be in range of 3.3V. I have to decide what gain i want. Which would be lower of course to cover the whole range. So the lower inputs will be close to noise to gain ratio 

Now if my range increases to 10V.
Now the gain can be 3 times higher and i can sense even the low currents with accuracy.
yeah... compromises suck. We know that.
adjustable gain externally, which is switched up when current drops?

Yes.
So I was thinking of an external adc with high input range and sync sampling.
high input range ADCs are fairly uncommon. sync sampling is also fairly uncommon. so the product of uncommon and uncommon is...
They are used in dc converter and motor controls.

Yes, I didn't say the need for +/-10V isn't common, I said that ADCs for that range are not common.

If you learn how to use the Parametric Seearch on Digikey or Mouser, you should be able to find what you need from what is available.

I don't know for how long this link is valid; https://www.digikey.com/en/products/filter/analog-to-digital-converters-adc/700?s=N4IgjCBcoKxaBjKAzAhgGwM4FMA0IB7KAbRABYAGAJgE4yAOEfS2smp86mmCkAXXwAHAC5QQAZWEAnAJYA7AOYgAvvioUA7PBBJIaLHkIkQAZhp0NvASBFjJsxSvwmyANm279OfEUikqlhr07ta2kBLS8kqqIK6uWtA6KBjeRn4g6iZg8fxCouH2USoxVMaoACZIfMpAA

There are the 6 choices (out of 14000 ADCs), well actually it is a single ADC,  that might fit what you are looking for. LTC2357 in either 16 or 18 bit variant. https://www.analog.com/media/en/technical-documentation/data-sheets/235716f.pdf

Do you guys have any idea how I can accurately transfer data between a STM32 to a Raspberry Pi? I'm using half-duplex (STM is slave and Pi is master) but I don't have a CS line. When I had a CS line the Pi was receiving data accurately but after removing it the Pi is no longer receiving accurate data from the STM32. I'm not sure how I can go about fixing this issue that I presume to be a synchronization issue without a MOSI line or CS line. Any advice?

Over SPI? I have never seen SPI with handshake wires/signals.
Length limit the "packets" to what is known can be handled by the other side, typically the buffer length. If transferring from slave to master, the request packet contains the offset and length and then the slave only transfers that, and once handled by the master a new request is made. For transfer in the opposite direction, if the master knows about the limitations of the slave, then just structure the transfer accordingly, again an offset and a length. If it is unknown, you might have a different request asking the slave how much it can receive before sending it. The STM32 should be set up to handle the entire "packet" with DMA and use interrupts to signal when a packet has arrive, and then send a "Done" or "Error" when completed and can handle a new request.

That is less important. But each block has a human readable line above it
PFP = Private Function Prototypes, which is written before the ones that it has put in itself.
As long as the C is valid, you could mess up what it "expects" in each block. Because it just conserves each block as-is when regenerating.
Oh I see. What about definitions?

```
#ifndef ALIGN_32BYTES
#if defined (__GNUC__)       /* GNU Compiler */
    #define ALIGN_32BYTES(buf)  buf __attribute__ ((aligned (32)))
#elif defined (__ICCARM__)   /* IAR Compiler */
    #define ALIGN_32BYTES(buf)  _Pragma("data_alignment = 32") buf
#elif defined (__CC_ARM)     /* Keil Compiler */
    #define ALIGN_32BYTES(buf)  __attribute__ ((aligned (32))) buf
#endif
```
Something like this for example
Just leave everything it generates. Much easier that way. The compiler will remove non-used code anyway.
That's code that I've written. I was wondering where I would add it?
I was trying to align my buffers to see if that would fix my DMA issues (it didn't)
oh, doesn't look like user code, since few people care about multiple compiler toolchains.
You stick that in a .h file in a User block. If it is already defined, then you need an #undef first
Yes, you need 32 bit alignment, Don't think you need anything larger than that.

Oh. Hmm.. I'm not too familiar with what defines that. Like I wouldn't have known on my own to put it in a .h file in a User block, I would have thought to just stick it in my main.c file. How do I know what goes where?

Excellent question; Anything that results in code being generated goes into .c files, and anything that the compiler needs to compile a single .c file goes into .h headers.

C compilation depends on the compiler processing each .c file individually, then afterwards bringing them altogether in the linker stage. So, if user1.c and user2.c both includes user.h, and user.h has a variable declaration (not a definition) then the linker will see two variables with the same name and complains.

The problem I was having is that I needed to send 4096 samples of 32 bit data from the STM32 to the Raspberry Pi 5 via SPI where the STM was slave and the Pi was master, but for some unknown reason the data would never consistently send over. Also, the Pi is unable to act as a slave because there is only support for it to function as a master. I would run into Overrun errors even if I sent only a few bytes of data at a very slow speed. The reason I wasn't able to figure it out is because it seemed like there were hardware limitations to either the STM or Pi, I still am not sure which one. There's a couple things here:

- When I turned the clock speed higher than 1 MHz, the transmissions would stop working.
- When I set the delay between transmissions to lower than 5 ms, the transmissions would stop working.
- If I tried sending more than 4096 bytes at a time, the transmission stopped working. This one was because spidev (Pi's SPI library) rate limits you to 4096 bytes per transmission
- The HAL library's Transmit/Receive functions expect 8 bit data per transmission (or 1 byte) and I needed to send 32 bits (or 4 bytes) per transmission. To get around this, I used a union which seemed to work out
- On the Pi side, I tried switching from Python to C in case Python was not fast enough, and that did not help. I still ran into the same issue.

In the end, setting my clock speed to 1 MHz, setting the delay to 5 ms, sending 4096 bytes per transmission is what seemed to work out. Essentially, I wasn't able to get it working at the speed that I needed it to be at (1.4 Megabytes per second), but it seems like my goal may have been too lofty to begin with (even though both the STM and Pi are rated to be able to handle those speeds)
I believe the RPI can function as a USB Host and the STM32 can most certainly function as a USB Device - so perhaps use USB?  1.4 MB/sec should be achievable.
I haven't tried that. Thank you for letting me know

messages.content:
Thx alot,
I saw that code and i see that you process the buff inside the interrupt.

Isn't it bad practice and we should avoide doing so?
In general yes but well - you have to do something with the characters received 😉  If you can think of a better way, I am all ears.

Typically, the buffer is handed over to "foreground" processing (be that the main loop, or a Task under FreeRTOS or similar) by some mechanism, which could either be copying the data somewhere else, or even tell the "foregraound" to process it in-line with the receiving buffer. Depends on the circumstances, and the level of robustness that one designs into a system. Other things that should be handled, but seldom is, are the overrun error and framing error, and a mechanism on each side to detect and recover from that. @Ariel
Joined the server.
Thanks alot, can you expend of framing and how to handle it?

Framing and Overrun (and Parity if used) errors refers to invalid bytes and inability to pick up shifted bytes quickly enough. IIRC, framing error is when the Stop bit is at the wrong level (should be HIGH, but is LOW). Overrun is probably not possible in DMA mode, since the hardware will move the received byte immediately. How to handle it, depends on higher level protocol. Could be timeout, could be sending an error code to the other party, even perhaps soft restarts in some cases.

Could someone explain the current sense part of this?
Why are there a bunch of resistors here, especially since VshuntU- is tied to ground so won't OPN/OPO just be ground? Is this circuit external or internal to the chip?
Page 37 of this btw https://www.st.com/resource/en/datasheet/stspin32g4.pdf

The shunts are externel, because, they has to handle lots of power.
The voltage over the shunt is proportional to the current, and becaus4 it's bound to GND, you can measure it with a simple integrated ADC.

OPP=OpAmp Positive Terminal, OPN=OpAmp Negative Terminal, OPO=OpAmp Output. Now, OPN/OPO resistors are the feedback resistor in a regular OpAmp set up, the resistors on OPP adds the offset needed to bring the opamp output to a positive voltage level. HTH.
But the datasheet said the op amp gain was programmable, so shouldn’t it not need an external feedback network?
I haven't checked the datasheet, but I assumed that your boxed "Current sense U" is external. Isn't it?

I am pretty sure it is external; The pins on the MCU speaks of OPAMPx_VINP, OPAMPx_VINN and OPAMPx_VOUT, where x is one of the 3 available ones. Nothing else is mentioned in the datasheet about it (other than pointing out that they exist).

messages.content:
Hi everyone! I am working on a school project comparing memory instruction behavior (LDR/STR) on ARM Cortex-M4 vs Cortex-M33 cores using automated benchmarking. I’ve hit a wall on the M33 and hope someone here has insight!

I am empirically benchmarking memory access instructions (my goal is mainly compare ldr, str instructions with various addressing modes) across: STM32F407VGTx (Cortex-M4, r0p1), STM32H503RB (Cortex-M33, r1p0)

Both run the same hand-crafted benchmarks under identical conditions, and I collect data from the DWT unit (CYCCNT, LSUCNT, CPICNT, FOLDCNT) using hardware breakpoints and PyOCD. The purpose is to analyze pipeline behavior and memory timings.

I built a minimal, modular benchmarking infrastructure: ELF Patcher: injects test code into precompiled, board-specific ELF files at a known symbol and a runner Flashes the ELF, enables DWT counters (CYCCNT, LSUCNT, CPICNT, FOLDCNT), resets them before testbench reads back counter values and dumps tables with the aquired data.Here’s a simple test, injected into a placeholder function (testbench) on both boards:
```
mov r0, sp
ldr r1, [r0, #0]
ldr r2, [r0, #4]
bx lr
```
I also mention that boards run this at 24 MHz, with all data accesses targeting stack SRAM.

| Counter      | M33 (STM32H503RB) | M4 (STM32F407VGTx) |
| ------------ | ----------------- | ------------------ |
| Instructions | 4                 | 4                 
| LSU                 | 0                 | 2              
| CPI                  | 13                | 2               
| Folded            | 1                 | 0                  
| Total Cycles  | 14                | 7                 

Despite the loads being aligned and hitting SRAM:
LSUCNT is always 0 on the STM32H5, the CPI is high and the M33 performs worse than M4, which is unexpected.  I am happy to share the code in private for any advice or shared experience would really help!  Thank you a lot!

Hello

Hi folks!  Wanted to introduce myself.  I've been working on an STM32 based software replacement for 1970s and 1980s ROMs for a a few months.  It's now fully functional and replaces 450ns and 350ns 2364, 2332 and 2316 ROMs in machines like the PET, VIC-20 and C64.  Can even replace up to 3 ROMs simultaneously with one replacement.

I ended up with the STM32 because I wanted an incredibly small footprint (same as the original ROMs) so wanted very few external parts, including no level shifters, no external oscillator, no external flash. STM32F4 ended up being pretty much perfect, given its better 5V support than the STM32F1, and great trade-off between performance and price.

Currently support F401, F411, F405 and F446, all clocked off the HSI/PLL, but also playing around with clones (GD32F405 seems OK, but has a much longer boot time than STM32, not sure why).  Even the F401 at 84MHz has just enough horsepower for the  fastest system (C64).

Everything's fully bare metal in C, with hand-rolled assembly main loop as every cycle counts.  No STM32 libraries, but am using segger_rtt for logging.  I have better luck flashing with my Raspberry Pi Debug Probe than I do with my clone st-link v2.

Toolchain wise, using GCC from ARM's development site, with a ton of pre- and post-processing tooling (that runs on a PC) written in Rust.

Decided against Rust for the STM32 development as although I like embassy-rs, felt too heavyweight for my bare-metal, performance optimised ROM code.

Hopefully links are allowed - project is at https://piers.rocks/u/sdrr if anyone's interested.  Source and hardware files all open source.

I have been kicking around the possibility of a Pico version as well, and took a look at PicoROM a few days ago, and how they achieve the timing to emulate the 27 series ROMs.  I don't think the PIO helps in this application - AIUI PicoROM is doing the byte lookup in assembly and then passing the byte to be written out to GPIOs via a FIFO to the PIO.

I _think_ it's possible to do it faster on the Pico than PicoROM is doing by setting your address pins ports 2-15, put pull-downs on GPIOs 0/1 and then read that in, mask it out and that as your offset into RAM.  Then use, say, 16-23 as the data lines, and, say, 24 as your OE line for the data line level shifter.  You need 64KB RAM for the ROM image you're serving because you need to store 32 bits for every byte served as it needs to store the actual value to be written to the 32-bit output register.   Only bits 16-23 and 24 are actually populated with data - 16-23 are the data bits to be served, bit 24 is 1 to enable the data ines.  You then just write this entire 32-bit value to the GPIO output register in one cycle.  Saves writing to the FIFO and then the PIO doing its thing.

I find it interesting that this is an area where the 16-bit GPIO ports really helps on the STM32 - you get many more options to avoid bit shifting/masking.  OTOH it makes the larger ROMs harder because once you blow past what you can do with 16 address lines you need much more complex manipulation.

messages.content: Never mind all that.... The USE_HAL_UART_REGISTER_CALLBACKS wasn't set and once that is set to 1 (in stm32f1xx_hal_conf.h), then it works. Shouldn't CubeMX be setting that?
Well, it does set it to zero. What am I missing?

And when putting it back to zero, it still works, so something else was affecting this, and now I can't stop it from working. Ah well... Mental note; SHOULD WORK, but something in CubeMX+CMake wanted to screw with me.

It's been quite a while since I made that video.  As far as I remember one point of confusion was/is that there are actually TWO interrupts being fired - the "idle event" AND the DMA half full event, so the callback need to check for that.

Ok, let me begin with this one.  The HAL libraries have "two" approaches when it comes to call backs. By default, it will call a specific "weak" function in the library which does nothing, that you can then overwrite in your code.  Alternatively, you can enable the register call backs, where you can just register any callback function.  This is configured in CubeMX here (right column):

Documented in the HAL source:
```
    ##### Callback registration #####
    ==================================

    [..]
    The compilation define USE_HAL_UART_REGISTER_CALLBACKS when set to 1
    allows the user to configure dynamically the driver callbacks.

    [..]
    Use Function HAL_UART_RegisterCallback() to register a user callback.
    Function HAL_UART_RegisterCallback() allows to register following callbacks:
    (+) TxHalfCpltCallback        : Tx Half Complete Callback.
    (+) TxCpltCallback            : Tx Complete Callback.
    (+) RxHalfCpltCallback        : Rx Half Complete Callback.
    (+) RxCpltCallback            : Rx Complete Callback.
    (+) ErrorCallback             : Error Callback.
    (+) AbortCpltCallback         : Abort Complete Callback.
    (+) AbortTransmitCpltCallback : Abort Transmit Complete Callback.
    (+) AbortReceiveCpltCallback  : Abort Receive Complete Callback.
    (+) MspInitCallback           : UART MspInit.
    (+) MspDeInitCallback         : UART MspDeInit.
    This function takes as parameters the HAL peripheral handle, the Callback ID
    and a pointer to the user callback function.

```
In my example I enabled the global interrupt on the receiving uart:
Notice, when using circular DMA buffer, the DMA stream interrupt is always enabled.

Without the register callback, the following callback will be called:
```
void HAL_UARTEx_RxEventCallback(UART_HandleTypeDef *huart, uint16_t offset)
```
Notice, the event callback is called when "idle" OR when the DMA buffer is half full, so have to check for that.
The primary use of the register callbacks would be if you want to handle multiple uarts in different ways but can't be arsed checking that in the actual callback.
My guess - you "forgot" to enable the global interrupt in the NVIC for the receiving uart.
I have probably only done that 50 times myself 😉
If the USE_HAL_UART_REGISTER_CALLBACKS is set to 1 and you have NOT registered a call back, I'd be surprised if it works.

Well, depends what one uses serial comms for. Most of my life it has been some type of serial protocol (Modbus, Exoline, BACnet,...) and then the "synch" happens in the protocol itself, most often with Master/Slave-oriented packets with start/end-of-packet and/or lengths. I recall in 1997 I implemented SPI, I2C, 1-wire and Exoline on a PIC16C73 (totally 192 bytes of RAM and 4kWord code), and Exoline has a theoretical max packet size of 243 bytes, but I decoded the packet while it was arriving, so only needed a few bytes of buffering and some flags. The main chunk of the 192 bytes of memory was to store the 64-bit 1-wire addresses for 16 devices. All in assembler of course, wouldn't be possible in C. Those were the days.

I might have mentioned this before, if so sorry; My first job was to create a real-time operating system with serial comms (RS-485) networking and loadable by customer programs, i.e. a PLC system (at that time the PLC term didn't exist, it was "PC" and they were only integer+boolean valuetype). Had to be able to run 16 task in parallel, with priority and settleable interval (how often to run from beginning, from 4ms to 25.5seconds). And first "working" version had 2kB of RAM to work with and 16kB of EPROM, on a 8031 (128bytes of internal registers). The OS itself used 256bytes for the scheduling (16 bytes each), just the floating point library took 4-5kB of EPROM memory because handling things from regular operators all the way up to trig and log functions. We even squeezed in a PID regulator in a couple of hundred bytes. Then one day, just around the first customer (end of 1985), the boss said "Well, RAM has become a lot cheaper, so 8kB will be the minimum" and we thought "Wow, soooo much space!", and we expanded the per task space to 32bytes per task. Then a few weeks later 32kB EPROM !! Gosh, how are we going to fill all that up?
And yeah, the entire implementation (incl compiler, editor and communication tools on the PC, of a brand new programming language) took ~4 man-years, and was actively sold until ~2010. (After the first couple of sales in 1986, I tried to change 8-bit year field to a 16 bit field, because of the Y2K problem down the line. "No. We will have re-written everything twice before then. And besides, we have already delivered 100 units and their software become incompatible." 
And of course; no dependencies anywhere. Well, we did depend on MS-DOS for the PC side of things, which means file access, since both serial ports and screen was direct hardware access back in those days.

I guess you will have to flip the read out protection to level 0 - but you will lose whatever is in the flash doing so.  You _can_ do that with the STM32CubeProgrammer.  See https://stm32world.com/wiki/STM32_Readout_Protection_(RDP)
